resource.description: The NCBI Taxonomy database contains the names of all organisms that are represented in the Entrez genetic databases.

The Sequence Ontology Project (SO) is a joint effort by genome annotation centres, including: WormBase, the Berkeley Drosophila Genome Project, FlyBase, the Mouse Genome Informatics group, and the Sanger Institute. They are a part of the Gene Ontology Project and their aim is to develop an ontology suitable for describing biological sequences.

ENZYME is a repository of information relative to the nomenclature of enzymes. It is primarily based on the recommendations of the Nomenclature Committee of the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB) and it describes each type of characterized enzyme for which an EC (Enzyme Commission) number has been provided
Gene Ontology annotation uses evidence codes to indicate the type of evidence that supports the annotation.
The Gene Ontology (GO) project provides a controlled vocabulary to describe gene and gene product attributes in any organism.
The Non-Redundant Database (NRDB) of protein sequences in FASTA format from GenBank.
InterPro is a database of protein families, domains and functional sites in which identifiable features found in known proteins can be applied to unknown protein sequences.
ESTs from the mirrored dbEST site.
Protein sequences from PDB used for mapping Plasmodium protein sequences to crystal structures in PDB.
PDB Identifiers

resource.displayName: L. braziliensis chromosomes sequence and annotation
resource.description:
Sequence data for Leishmania braziliensis clone M2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) were downloaded from GeneDB (sequence and annotated features).
Sequencing of L. braziliensis was conducted by The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit.

resource.displayName: L. infantum chromosomes sequence and annotation
resource.description:
Sequence data for Leishmania infantum clone JPCM5 (MCAN/ES/98/LLM-877) were downloaded from GeneDB (sequence and annotated features).
Sequencing of L. infantum was conducted by The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit.

resource.displayName: L. major chromosomes sequence and annotation, version 5.2
resource.description:
Sequence data for Leishmania major Friedlin (reference strain - MHOM/IL/80/Friedlin, zymodeme MON-103) were downloaded from GeneDB (sequence and annotated features).
Sequencing of L. major was conducted by The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit, Seattle Biomedical Research Institute and The European Leishmania major Friedlin Genome Sequencing Consortium.

resource.displayName: T. brucei chromosomes sequence and annotation, release 4
resource.description:
Sequence data for Trypanosome brucei strain TREU (Trypanosomiasis Research Edinburgh University) 927/4 were downloaded from GeneDB (sequence and annotated features).
Sequencing of T. brucei was conducted by The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit and TIGR.

resource.pluginArgs: --externalDatabaseSpec "%EXT_DB_NAME%|%EXT_DB_RLS_VER%" --inputFile @downloadDir@/GOAssociations_Lmajor/gene_association.GeneDB_Lmajor.060308 --goExternalDatabaseSpec "Gene Ontology|4.490" --seqIdSql "SELECT g.source_id, taf.aa_sequence_id FROM dots.genefeature g, dots.transcript t, dots.translatedAAFeature taf WHERE g.na_feature_id = t.parent_id AND t.na_feature_id = taf.na_feature_id" --targetTable "DoTS::TranslatedAASequence" --lineOfEvidence "GeneDB" --inputIdColumn id --tolerateMissingSeqs --skipBadGOTerms @pipelineDir@/logs/badGOTerms.log
resource.description: L. major Gene Ontology associations from GeneDB.

Tremblay, Frédéric Raymond, Sébastien Boisvert from Université Laval, and Martin Olivier from McGill University). The CIHR group plans on publishing the completed and annotated sequences in a peer-reviewed journal as soon as possible. Permission should be obtained from Marc Ouellette before publishing analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes on a chromosome or genome scale.

resource.extDbRlsDescrip: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation data from Peter Myler lab
resource.description: The chromosomal location of TATA-binding protein (TBP or TRF4), Small Nuclear Activating Protein complex (SNAP50), and H3 histones were assessed in Leishmania major using microarrays hybridized with DNA obtained through chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP-chip). The TBP and SNAP50 binding patterns were almost identical and high intensity peaks were associated with tRNAs and snRNAs. Only 184 peaks of acetylated H3 histone were found in the entire genome, with substantially higher intensity in rapidly-dividing cells than stationary-phase. The majority of the acetylated H3 peaks were found at divergent strand-switch regions, but some occurred at chromosome ends and within polycistronic gene clusters. Almost all these peaks were associated with lower intensity peaks of TBP/SNAP50 binding a few kilobases upstream, evidence that they represent transcription initiation sites. Contact Peter Myler, peter.myler@sbri.org, Seattle Biomedical Research Institute.
